diagnoses: Lower back pain related to pregnancy
advice: Stay hydrated. Aim for 8-10 glasses of water daily.
Take prenatal vitamins as prescribed.
Maintain a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and lean proteins.
Get regular moderate exercise such as walking for 30 minutes daily.
Avoid alcohol, smoking, and recreational drugs during pregnancy.
Limit caffeine intake to less than 200mg per day (about one cup of coffee).
Elevate legs when sitting or lying down to reduce swelling.
Sleep on your left side to improve blood flow to the fetus.
Wear supportive shoes and consider a pregnancy support belt for back pain.
Practice relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation for stress management.
Avoid raw or undercooked meats, fish, and eggs.
Avoid unpasteurized dairy products and juices.
Track fetal movements daily from week 28 onwards.
Rest when tired and avoid overexertion.
Contact healthcare provider immediately if experiencing severe headache, visual disturbances, or abdominal pain.
Schedule childbirth education classes in the third trimester.

complaints: Shortness of breath during third trimester
advice: Maintain a regular sleep schedule and create a comfortable sleep environment.
Eat small, frequent meals to manage nausea and heartburn.
Stay physically active with prenatal-approved exercises like swimming or walking.
Use a pregnancy pillow for better sleep positioning.
Practice pelvic floor exercises (Kegels) daily.
Wear supportive maternity belt for back pain relief.
Increase dietary fiber and water intake to prevent constipation.
Monitor blood glucose regularly if diagnosed with gestational diabetes.
Avoid standing for long periods; take frequent breaks.
Apply cold or warm compresses for muscle aches as recommended.
Count fetal kicks daily in the third trimester and report changes.
Consider prenatal massage by a certified therapist for pain relief.
Prepare hospital bag by 36 weeks of pregnancy.
Discuss birth plan options with healthcare provider.
Attend all scheduled prenatal appointments.
Report any unusual symptoms promptly to healthcare provider.
